Award.AwardTitle: II-NEW: Shared High Performance Data Center

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The creation, management, and access of data is key to the advancement of the state-of-the-art in computer science. Currently many research and educational activities in social network, web mining, multimedia retrieval, and high performance computing, just to name a few, need to involve big data. However, existing infrastructure of the Computer Science Department at Texas State University falls far behind its increasing research and educational needs.

This project builds a shared high-performance data center, providing the fundamental facilities to collect, process, and manage large volumes of data. The new data center supplies the necessary computational power and storage to support the exploration and development of new research and technologies within and beyond the department in the fields of computer vision, wireless network, information retrieval, data mining, human computer interaction, software engineering, high performance computing, and security. The data center also supports quality undergraduate and graduate student research experience, enables the integration of research and education, encourages inter-departmental and cross-university collaborations, and promotes the Ph.D. program development in the Computer Science Department. The developed infrastructure will significantly enhance the current research and educational capabilities of the department, university, and community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CRI grant has supported construction of a shared high performance data center that provides extensive educational and research benefits to the faculty members and students in the Computer Science department at Texas State University and beyond: 1) The constructed infrastructure provides the necessary facilities to enable the collection, storage, and management of large volumes of data for research and education in information retrieval, data mining, wireless network, high-performance computing, and computer vision. 2) The infrastructure provides the necessary computational power to support the analysis of large-scale research data, upon which new data models and methodologies can be explored and developed. 3) The shared high-performance data center presents many opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at Texas State and REU participating students to gain valuable research experiences. 4) The data sets and systems created have been incorporated into undergraduate and graduate classes at all levels, as well as interdisciplinary educational programs (e.g., Geoinformatics and Computer Engineering) and collaborative projects across campus. Thus, the data center provides unique learning and training opportunities for students from the entire university. 5) The high quality data sets generated in the infrastructure are made publicly accessible, which greatly benefit the broader scientific community. 6) The infrastructure largely enhances research and education capabilities of CS department at Texas State, and significantly boost CS Ph.D. program development. The CRI grant has led to fruitful results in the past five years.

 1)      Data Center: with this CRI grant, six high-performance workstations and five laptops were purchased and provided to faculty, undergraduate and graduate students to perform complex computation for their research projects. Two high-end servers including a NVIDIA GPU server, four external storage devices, one BioHarness sensor from Zephyr Technology, two Jawbone Up wristband and one Samsung Galaxy S4 were purchased for research projects. A shared high performance data center was built and benefited many projects and numerous faculty and students at Texas State.

 2)      Activities: 48 research projects were supported for research and education in the fields of information retrieval, data mining, wireless network, high-performance computing, and computer vision. These projects generated many novel algorithms and new technologies, leading to significant contributions within and beyond the discipline.  

3)      Training: 1 Post-doc, 15 graduate students and 5 undergraduate students directly participated in the research projects supported by this CRI grant. Three NSF REU programs were supported by this CRI grant: “REUMCPS: Mobile Cyber-Physical Systems”, “REUIOT: Multidisciplinary Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Internet of Things”, and “REUSSA: Research Experiences in Software Systems and Analysis”. 58 undergraduate REU students and two high school teachers from diverse institutions participated in these programs. The infrastructure has provided the necessary servers and 11 desktop computers for all the REU students. These research projects helped undergraduate students gain research experiences and interests.

4)      Publications: Research supported by this grant has generated 83 published papers in highly recognized journals (e.g., Transactions on Multimedia, Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems, and Transactions on Cybernetics) and conferences (e.g., ACM Multimedia, CIKM). In addition, two papers have been submitted, and one paper is underway to be submitted in 2019.

5)      Funding: 4 external and 3 internal research grants were funded with support of this CRI grant, including NSF-REUMCPS, NSF-REUIOT, NSF-REUSSA, NVIDIA Academic Grant, Texas State University Multi-disciplinary Internal Research Grant program, and Texas-State Research Enhancement Program.

6)      Data and Systems: Seven datasets were created and open for public, including 3D shape retrieval benchmark datasets and web service datasets.  An application for a systematic data-driven approach to analyze the current job market for Ph.D. holders in CS:  Career Explorer (http://eil.cs.txstate.edu/CareerExplorer), a system for optimizing health based on a person’s genetic halogroup: GeneticEve (http://pluto.cs.txstate.edu/GeneticTesting/), and a web service similarity search engine ServiceXplorer (http://eil.cs.txstate.edu/WSXplore) were built and maintained. The collected datasets, developed systems, and constructed REU websites are all hosted on the above servers.

7)      Education: The collected datasets and research results have been integrated into various levels of classes in the Computer Science Department. Students from these classes are able to use the datasets and systems to gain first-hand experience and intuition in the fundamental concepts and research frontiers of data mining, machine learning, computer vision, and web technology. The relevant graduate courses include CS5332 (Database Theory and Design), CS5369U (Advanced Data Mining), CS5375 (Multimedia Computing), CS5369L (Machine Learning and its Applications), CS5376 (Enterprise Application Integration), and CS5369G (Web Services Engineering). The relevant undergraduate courses include CS4332 (Introduction to Database Systems), CS4378U (Data Mining), CS4378V (Introduction to Machine Learning), and CS2388 (Internet Programming on the World Wide Web).

With the support of this CRI grant, a new Ph.D. program in Computer Science was successfully developed. 22 Ph.D. students were recruited and started their training and professional development to date. The servers and computers purchased with this CRI grant are used as basic computation machines for the new developed Ph.D. lab.
